name: Teaching Guide: Exploring the Politics of Frederick Douglass and Abraham Lincoln

affiliation.name: Lexington School District One, South Carolina

hasPart.name: Questions
hasPart.text:
1. Use the [excerpt from the Chesnutt biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/94), the [chapter from Douglass’s autobiography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/97), and the [excerpt from the Noah Brooks biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/98) to delve into the biographies of Abraham Lincoln and Frederick Douglass. Using textual evidence, describe three aspects of each of their lives that propelled them to a life of service and advocating for others. 

2. How did Lincoln’s view on slavery develop throughout his life? Give specific examples from the [texts of two Lincoln speeches](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/99) and the [Emancipation Proclamation](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/100). 

3. Cite textual evidence from the [excerpt from the Chesnutt biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/94), the [excerpt from an 1847 Frederick Douglass speech](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/95), the [text of “What, to a slave, is the Fourth of July?”](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/96), and the [chapter from Douglass’s autobiography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/97) to discuss Frederick Douglass’s stance on the institution of slavery. Did Douglass believe slavery was incompatible with American democracy?

4. What was Douglass’s “true north?” Use the [texts of two Lincoln speeches](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/99), the [Emancipation Proclamation](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/100), the [1888 reminiscence by Frederick Douglass](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/101), and the [1876 speech given by Frederick Douglass](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/104) to determine how Lincoln’s stances and conclusions compare to Douglass’s. 

5. What are the striking features of Freedmen’s Statue as seen in the [photograph](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/105)? Explain the words Douglass used to describe Lincoln in his [1876 speech](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/104). How do you believe this speech and statue were perceived in the 1870s? How could they be viewed in a twenty-first century context?

hasPart.name: Activity
hasPart.text: Using the [1879 photographic portrait of Frederick Douglass](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/92), the [excerpt from the Chesnutt biography](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/94), the [excerpt from an 1847 Frederick Douglass speech](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/95), the [text of “What, to a slave, is the Fourth of July?”](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/96), the [Emancipation Proclamation](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/100), the [1888 reminiscence by Frederick Douglass](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/101), the [1876 speech given by Frederick Douglass](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/104), and the [photograph of Freedmen’s Statue](http://dp.la/primary-source-sets/sources/105) as a guide, students should consider how Abraham Lincoln might have memorialized Frederick Douglass if the order of their deaths had been reversed. In groups of two to four, students should write a speech and develop plans for a memorial which would honor Frederick Douglass. The speech and plans should be developed from Lincoln’s perspective on the life, work, and accomplishments of Douglass. Students should present their speech and memorial plans to the class. This is a project which could appeal to all learners: auditory, visual, and kinesthetic.
